title-group.article-title: Association of Adiponectin Gene Polymorphism (+T45G) With Acute Coronary Syndrome and Circulating Adiponectin Levels

article-meta.aff: 1Health Sciences, College of Arts and Sciences, Qatar University, Doha, Qatar
2Cardiology Department, Heart Hospital, Hamad Medical Corporation (HMC), Doha, Qatar
3Clinical Medicine, Weill Cornell Medical School, Doha, Qatar
5Clinical Chemistry Department, Hamad Medical Corporation, Doha, Qatar

author-notes.corresp: Nasser M. Rizk, Biomedical Science Program, Faculty of Science, College of Arts and Sciences, Qatar University, PO Box 2713, Doha, Qatar. Email: nassrizk@qu.edu.qa

abstract.p: We investigated the association of adiponectin gene polymorphisms (+T45G and +G276T) and adiponectin levels with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) among Arabs in Qatar. A case–control study was performed in 142 Arab patients with ACS and 122 controls. Genotypes were determined using TaqMan real-time polymerase chain reaction assay. The TT, TG, and GG genotype frequencies of the T45G variant were significantly different among cases and controls (P = .023) but not significant for G276T genotypic frequencies. It was found that only the +45G allele was significantly associated with 3-fold increased risk of ACS (odds ratio = 2.77; 1.03-6.96; P = .043) among patients, using the genetic recessive model. Carriers of GG alleles had significantly lower adiponectin levels compared to TT/TG carriers of T45G in patients with ACS. The present study suggests that only T45G single-nucleotide polymorphism in the adiponectin gene is associated with higher odds for ACS events and has an effect on serum adiponectin levels among Arab populations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Adiponectin is a hormone secreted by adipocytes 1 that has a number of antiatherogenic properties. 2 Adiponectin is thought to be extensively deposited in the interstitium of vascular lesions of patients with myocardial infarction (MI). 3 In humans, a decreased adiponectin concentration may be a risk factor for atherosclerosis 1,4 and has been linked to the presence of coronary artery diseases (CADs). 5 Adiponectin is the most abundant hormone circulating in the plasma (∼10-30 μg/mL or ∼0.01% of plasma proteins). It is present primarily in 3 forms: a low-molecular-weight (LMW) trimer of approximately 67 kDa, a hexamer of ∼120 kDa and a high-molecular-weight (HMW) multimer of >300 kDa. The HMW form has been shown to possess the most potent insulin-sensitizing and anti-atherosclerotic effects. Defects in adiponectin level and its HMW form are associated with obesity, atherosclerosis, and cardiovascular disease (CVD). 6 Moreover, plasma adiponectin concentrations are significantly lower in obese participants than in nonobeseparticipants. 1 Ostial coronary artery levels of adiponectin in acute coronary syndrome (ACS) may indicate redistribution of adiponectin molecules toward the acute lesions. 7

The human adiponectin gene is located in chromosome 3q27 that is known to be the susceptibility locus for metabolic syndrome and type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) and is encoded by 3 exons which span approximately 16 kb. 8,9 The genetic polymorphism of rs2241766 (+T45G) and rs1501299 (+G276T) in the exon 2 and intron 2 has been frequently associated with type 2 DM, obesity, and CAD. 10
–14

A genetic deficit of this protein might increase the risk of ACS events in both the general population and type 2 diabetic patients especially with decreased HMW adiponectin/total adiponectin ratio. 7 Two single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) at the adiponectin locus (T45G) and (G276T) have been associated with low serum adiponectin levels, insulin resistance, and DM. 10,15 Therefore, it could be postulated that these SNPs may also play a role in the development of MI and ACS through its effect on adiponectin biology.

This study was based on our previous finding that circulating adiponectin levels are lower in patients with ACS. 6 Hence, we evaluated the association of adiponectin gene polymorphisms (T45G and G276T) and circulating adiponectin levels with the odds of ACS events among Arab population. We also assessed the association of these SNPs with the angiographic changes (number of blood vessels involved) and left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) among patients with ACS.

sec.title: Study Participants
sec.p: A case–control study was performed in 264 unrelated Arab participants (142 patients with ACS and 122 controls), residing in Qatar, and the participants were enrolled for the study from March 2008 to May 2010. Participants with age ranging from 30 to 70 years (males or females) with a definite diagnosis of non-ST and ST elevation MI according to the American College of Cardiology criteria were included in the study. All patients were consecutively enrolled based on either symptoms consistent with acute MI or electrocardiographic changes in at least 2 contiguous leads and had serum markers of myocardial necrosis (creatine kinase MB and troponin) levels twice the upper limit of normal. The time from the onset of symptoms to admission to the intensive care unit had to be less than 24 hours. The control group included healthy volunteers who attended the blood bank of the Hamad General Hospital.

Participants with type 2 DM were diagnosed according to the World Health Organization (WHO) criteria. 16 Dyslipidemia was diagnosed based on the criteria of National Cholesterol Education Program Adult Treatment Panel III. 17 Hypertension was defined as a systolic and/or diastolic blood pressure (BP) ≥140 and/or ≥90 mm Hg, respectively, or a significant history of hypertension and/or under antihypertensive medication. The cutoff point for body mass index (BMI) was based on the WHO criteria. 18 Individuals with other diseases such as cancer, autoimmune disorders, and advanced renal and liver complications were excluded. Informed consent was obtained from each participant after detailed explanation about the study. The institutional review board has approved the study.

sec.title: Clinical and Biochemical Investigations
sec.p: Height, weight, systolic, and diastolic BP of the patients were measured by a trained professional in the clinic. Ten milliliters of peripheral blood were collected from each participant. Five milliliters were used for DNA extraction and the remaining 5 mL for determination of biochemical and hormonal parameters. Serum concentrations of total cholesterol, triglycerides, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), glucose, and cardiac markers were also measured. Serum insulin and adiponectin levels were measured by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (Millipore, MA, USA), according to the manufacturer’s instructions, in the Biomedical Laboratory, Department of Health Sciences, Qatar University. Left ventricular ejection fraction was determined at the cardiology department.

sec.title: Genomic DNA Isolation
sec.p: DNA was extracted from venous blood samples of all cases and controls using QiaAmp DNA blood Mini Kit (Qiagen, Germany), with red blood cell lyses solution (Qiagen). DNA extraction was performed according to the manufacturer protocol. Measurements of DNA concentration and purity were assessed using nanodrop Spectrophotometer 1000 (Thermo Scientific, Wilmington, Delaware).

sec.title: Genotypic Characterization of Adiponectin (T45G and G276T) Gene Variants Using Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction
sec.p: Based upon previous report, 19 2 tagged SNPs (T45G and G276T) in the adiponectin gene were selected for the present study. Analysis of these SNPs was carried out based on 5′ nuclease assay by TaqMan MGB probe using ABI 7500 (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, California). The primers and probes were obtained from assay-on demand TM service of Applied Biosystems. Briefly, the 5′ nuclease assay was performed using 20 ng genomic DNA, 1× TaqMan Universal PCR Master Mix (Applied Biosystems), 1× primer/probe mix, and optimal cycling conditions for polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplification as provided by the manufacturer. Negative and positive controls were also included for quality controls.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Data are expressed as mean and 95% confidence interval (CI) for continuous variables and by number and percentage for categorical data. All statistical analyses were performed using the SPSS program for Windows (version 19 statistical software; Texas instruments, Illinois) and Golden Helix’ SNP & Variation Suite (SVS 7; Bozeman, Montana), for genetic analysis. Differences between continuous variables were evaluated accordingly by Student t test (2-tailed) and analysis of variance wherever applicable. Nonparametric Mann-Whitney and 2 independent samples t tests were used accordingly for analysis. Genotype distribution and allelic frequencies between the study groups were compared by constructing 2 × 2 contingency tables, and chi-square test (χ2) or Fischer exact test corrected for Bonferroni adjustment for the number of SNPs. The Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium (HWE) was performed using χ2 test to assess the genotype distribution in all study participants. Three genetic models, that is, dominant minor allele, recessive minor allele, and additive models (additional copy of the risk alleles increases the response by an equal amount) were analyzed. Odds ratio (ORs), 95% CI, and corresponding P values were analyzed by logistic regression analysis and adjusted accordingly. The ORs were computed using the minor allele homozygous as the reference group unless mentioned otherwise. A 2-tailed P <.05 was considered significant.

sec.title: Characteristics of Patient Population
sec.p: Among 264 participants, 142 patients presented with ACS with a mean age of 53.5 (51.0-54.6 years), 91% were males, 25% were hypertensive, and 49% had DM. Dyslipidemia and BMI were comparable between the ACS and control groups (32% vs 27%, P = .58 and 28% vs 30%, P = .06, respectively). Serum insulin levels were higher in the ACS group (33.36 µU/mL; 27.35-39.37) compared with the control group (22.09 µU/mL; 12.06-32.12), whereas the serum adiponectin levels were lower in ACS group (7.00 µg/mL; 5.86-8.15) than in controls (9.35 µg/mL; 8.09-10.62, P = .01; Table 1). Overall, the SNP genotypes and allelic frequencies were determined in 264 individuals. All examined AdipoQ gene polymorphisms were in HWE (P > .05). For T45G, the P value of HWE was .244 and .152 and for G276T was 0.394 and 0.521 among control and cases, respectively. A significant difference was observed in genotypic distribution of T45G (P = .023; Table 2) between ACS and control participants. However, the frequency of G276T genotypes was comparable among cases and controls (P = .982). Moreover, the genotypic distribution of AdipoQ gene polymorphisms (T45G and G276T) was not statistically different among patients with ACS based on the presence of DM and the number of obstructive coronary arteries (Figures 1 and 2). Figure 3 shows the distribution of T45G polymorphism according to LVEF. There was a trend for more GG genotype among patients with lower LVEF (<40%). The genotypic distribution of AdipoQ gene polymorphisms (T45G and G276T) was not statistically different among patients with ACS based on gender, hypertension, hypertriglyceridemia, low HDL-C, high LDL-C, and hypercholesterolemia (Table 3).

caption.p: Clinical and Biochemical Data of Patients With Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) and Controls.a

fn.p: Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; TC, total cholesterol; TG, triglyceride; LDL-C, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol; HDL-C, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol; CK-MB, creatine kinase MB protein.

a Continuous data are presented as means (95% confidence interval). Categorical variables are presented as number (percentage). Mean difference in glucose, LDL, HDL, TC, TG, insulin, and adiponectin are adjusted for age, gender, and BMI.

caption.p: Genotype Distribution of Adiponectin Gene Polymorphisms (+45T>G and +276G>T) in Patients With ACS and Controls.

fn.p: Abbreviations: ACS, acute coronary syndrome; SNP, single-nucleotide polymorphism.
a P < .05 is considered statistically significant.

caption.p: Genotype Distribution Based on Gender, Hypertension, and Lipid Profile.a

fn.p: Abbreviations: HTN, hypertension; HDL-C, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol; LDL-C, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol.

a Data are presented as number and (percentage). P value is significant at <.05. χ2 = chi-square with 1 degree of freedom. Hypercholesterolemia based on cutoff value of desirable level of 5.18 mmol/L (no = below, yes = above this value), and for LDL-C on cutoff value of 3.37 mmol/L (no = below, yes = above this value). Both TG and HDL-C are based on clinical criteria for metabolic syndrome for TG = 1.695 mmol/L and for HDL-C (males = 1.036 mmol/L and females = 1.295 mmol/L) with no = below; yes = above this value.

caption.p: Genotype distribution of T45G and G276T polymorphisms in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) with (ACS + DM) and without diabetes (ACS − DM). DM indicates diabetes mellitus.
Genotype distribution of T45G and G276T polymorphisms in acute coronary syndrome (ACS) according to the number of blood vessels affected.
Genotype distribution of T45G and G276T polymorphisms in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) based upon ejection fraction above and below 40.0%.

sec.title: Association Between ACS and Adiponectin Gene Polymorphism (T45G and G276T) Based on Genetic Models
sec.p: The minor allele frequency (G allele) for T45G was 0.340 and 0.415 between control and patients with ACS, respectively. The minor allele frequency (T allele) for G276T was 0.376 and 0.365 in control and patients with ACS, respectively. Using the recessive genetic model for T45G (GG/TG+TT), carriers of GG genotype had an increased risk of ACS event by 2.8-fold (1.03-6.96, P = .043). In addition using the additive genetic models (GG+TG/TT), the G allele carriers had no significant risk of ACS event. Furthermore, GG/TT genotype had significant odds of 2 times for ACS (unadjusted OR [aOR] = 2.08; 0.02-0.69; P = .042) and GG/TG had a 4-fold increased risk of ACS (aOR = 3.85; 1.10-13.49; P = .035), as shown in Table 4. On the other hand, no significant association was observed for G276T polymorphism for TT carriers compared with GG/TG alleles with respect to the risk of ACS events among study participants under different genetic models (Table 4).

caption.p: Risk Analysis of Adiponectin Gene Polymorphisms (T45G and G276T) According to Genotype Models Among ACS Cases and Controls.a

fn.p: Abbreviations: ACS, acute coronary syndrome; SNP, single nucleotide polymorphism; BMI, body mass index; LDL-C, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol; 95% CI, 95% confidence interval.
a P < .05 is considered significant. Odds ratios are adjusted for age, BMI gender, LDL-C, glucose, insulin and adiponectin.

sec.title: Serum Adiponectin Level and SNPT45G and G276T Among Patients With ACS
sec.p: Figure 4 shows that patients with GG genotypes of T45G polymorphism had a significantly lower serum adiponectin level compared with patients carrying TT and/or TG genotypes. No significant change in adiponectin level was detected among different genotypes for G276T polymorphisms. Furthermore, the recessive genetic model for T45G (P = .01 and β coefficient = −4.39) was the only significant determinant of adiponectin gene among patients with ACS (Table 5). This independent factor explained 27% of the variation in the response variable (adiponectin) in ACS (P = .005) using this model. We analyzed the association between the serum adiponectin and the other significant variables (age, BMI, blood glucose, and HDL-C) included in the complete cohort of patients with ACS as the dependent variables and both SNPs as the independent variables. The results of multivariate correlations (Figure 4) only showed a significant relationship between adiponectin as dependent variable and recessive genetic model for T45G as independent variables in patients with ACS.

caption.p: Serum adiponectin level based upon genotype distribution among T45G and G276T polymorphisms in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS). P value is significantly different than GG carriers (*, ∂) for T45G.
Multiple Regression Analysis of Serum Adiponectin Levels With Age, BMI, HDL, Glucose, and SNPs (+45T>G and +276G>T) Among Patients With ACS.a

fn.p: Abbreviations: ACS, acute coronary syndrome; BMI, body mass index; SNP, single nucleotide polymorphism; HDL-C, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol.
a P < .05 for levels of β-coefficient at 2-tailed testing.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The present study reports adiponectin polymorphism among the Arab patients with ACS. The key findings are (i) there is a significant association of T45G SNP with a higher risk of having ACS for GG carriers, (ii) circulating adiponectin levels are significantly lower in GG genotypes of T45G among patients with ACS, (iii) no significant association of SNP G276T with ACS, (iv) there is no significant association DM, and number of blood vessels affected for both T45G and G276T polymorphism, and (v) LVEF is significantly different only according to the genotype distributions of T45G polymorphism in ACS. The implications of these findings are discussed below.

Among approximately 10 adiponectin gene polymorphisms reported until now, T45G was associated with the increased risk of insulin resistance and type 2 DM. 20 –22 Several studies have demonstrated strong genetic associations between adiponectin and CVD. 1,2,6 In the present study, T to G mutation at T45G of adiponectin gene increases the odds of ACS even after adjustment for potential confounding factors. In contrast, the SNP G276T has no significant association of ACS events among the study participants. Considering the association of the SNP T45G with ACS, our findings are in agreement with other studies from French, Swiss, Iranian Saudi, and Afro-Caribbean involving type 2 diabetic patients. 12,13,23,24

Lacquemant and coworkers investigated the associations of 6 SNPs (−11377C>G, −4041A>C, +45T>G, +276G>T, +349A>G, and +2019delA) with CAD in cohorts of French and Swiss type 2 diabetic patients. An association between the +45T>G SNP and CAD was observed in both cohorts separately, as well as when the 2 groups were pooled. 23 GG homozygotes and GT heterozygotes of +45T>G combined presented an increased risk of CAD as compared to TT homozygotes (OR: 2.0; 95% CI: 1.3-3.2; P = .02). 23 In addition, Boumaiza et al, among Tunisian population with significant coronary stenosis (SCS), demonstrated that mutated genotypes at +45T/G (GG+TG) were associated with an increase in SCS only in the obese group. 25 The current data are consistent with the study by Al-Daghri et al which showed that SNP45T>G of adiponectin gene was significantly associated with the risk of CAD (OR; 95% CI, 4.7; 1.6-13.5, P < .003) but not SNP276G>T (OR; 95% CI, 1.02; 0.53-1.9, P > .05) among patients with type 2 DM in Saudi Arabia. 12 Moreover, these studies reported a lack of an association of SNP G276T with CAD in Saudi patients with type 2 DM12 and in French and Swiss patients. 23

Among Brazilians, the SNP45T>G and SNP276G>T polymorphisms were associated with CAD. 26 Our data, however, contrast with other studies, 13,27,28 which showed that SNP G276T had an association with the risk of CAD among type 2 diabetic patients. Esteghamati et al demonstrated that SNP+276G>T is associated with decreased risk of CAD but not the +45T>G SNP among Iranian patients with type 2 DM. 27 Jang et al reported that the presence of the G allele in the adiponectin gene at SNP 276 could be a significant contributor to higher CVD risk in Koreans, 29 while another study among Korean participants showed that +45T>G and 276G>T polymorphisms were not associated with CAD. 19 In addition, a recent study by Pischon et al demonstrated that both +45T>G and +276G>T SNPs are not involved in the development of CAD. 30 The inconsistency in these studies could be explained by the small sample size, ethnic background, or environmental factors.

The current data among patients with ACS showed no significant association of both +45T>G and +276G>T SNPs in the number of coronary vessels affected. A limited number of studies have addressed this association. A similar finding to our study showed no association for the blood vessels affected by the presence of CAD with the genotype distribution of +45T>G and +276G>T SNPs. 19 In contrast, among Tunisian, the mutated genotypes at the +45T/G polymorphism were significantly associated with increased SCS only in obese patients. 25 To our knowledge, no single study has been conducted so far to investigate the association of LVEF among patients with ACS with +45T>G and +276G>T SNPs of the adiponectin gene. Further studies are needed to explore this relationship.

Lower levels of circulating adiponectin were reported in patients with ACS, CAD, and cardiovascular risk. 7,31
–35 Moreover, the association of AdipoQ SNPs with circulating adiponectin has been assessed in several studies. 14,15,36 –38 In Japanese patients with type 2 DM, SNP+45 was associated with reduced adiponectin levels. 10 In order to test the effects of +45T>G and +276G>T SNPs on adiponectin levels, we measured serum adiponectin in patients with ACS. T SNP+45T>G was associated with decreased levels of adiponectin in patients with ACS. Previous studies also found significant associations between adiponectin levels and ADIPOQ variants 27,36,39 in a meta-analysis for which more than 2000 individuals have been studied. 40 In addition, Woo et al studied white and African American adolescents and found that the haplotypes formed by SNPs 45, 276, and 349 were associated with low adiponectin levels in Whites but not in African Americans. 41

In the present study, serum adiponectin levels were reduced in carriers of GG alleles of T45G in patients with ACS and the data of multiple regression analysis demonstrated that total adiponectin concentrations among ACS are associated with SNP T45G only. The T45G polymorphism located in exon 2 of the AdipoQ gene is suggested to be in linkage disequilibrium (LD) with other variants such as −1377 and −11391 SNPs of the 5/promoter region. 37 Variations in the LD between populations may explain the inconsistent association with T45G SNP and adiponectin levels among different populations. 42,43 The SNP T45G could be a marker for a variant 3/UTR region via LD that could accelerate the degradation of messenger RNA (mRNA) with decreased adiponectin protein levels 44 and/or that exonic SNP affects the mRNA splicing and changes the protein levels. 45 Inconsistent with the current data, Mousavinasab et al showed that the T276T genotype of the adiponectin gene in young Finnish men was associated with elevated serum adiponectin but not T45G. 46 The association of GG genotype with the marked decrease in total adiponectin levels in these patients may confer the increased odds of ACS events among patients carrying GG genotype of T45G.

The study has several limitations such as the relatively small number of patients, its cross-sectional nature, and less female participants. This small number of females does not reflect the number of women with ACS (in our cardiology unit) but reflects the number who consented.

In summary, we observed an association between the +45T>G SNP with ACS and lower adiponectin concentrations especially among GG carriers. No significant association of G276T with ACS and adiponectin levels was observed. Both SNPs have no significant effect or association with affected blood vessels and LVEF in ACS. The assessment of AdipoQ gene polymorphism (T45G) with simultaneous measurement of total adiponectin may be helpful in detecting the risk of getting ACS among Arab patients, in conjunction with other clinical data.

Further studies are needed with larger samples to screen for polymorphism of the entire adiponectin gene and other genes. Subsequent functional studies of the identified SNPs will help understand the molecular mechanisms of any observed association.

ack.p: We are grateful to the staff of Cardiology, Biochemistry and Medical Research center in Hamad Medical Corporation (HMC), Biomedical department, Qatar University and Alshafallah Genetic Center for their efforts and cooperation. Special thanks to Mrs Mooza Alkhinji, senior lab technician at Qatar University for her technical support. Its contents are solely the responsibility of the authors and do not necessarily represent the official views of the Qatar National Research Fund.

fn.p: Part of this study was presented in The European Congress on Obesity: Annual Scientific Meeting, May 6-9, 2009, Amsterdam, the Netherlands.
